trial_identification.studytitle: The Effect of Zinc Supplementation on Expression of Zinc Transporters in Healthy Individuals
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The Effect of Zinc Supplementation on Expression of Zinc Transporters in Healthy Individuals

interventions.interventions: Zinc Chelate 220mg (22mg elemental zinc), one tablet per day for 21 days administered orally (TGA registry - ARTG 128690). Compliance will be checked by tablet return and plasma zinc levels.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Zinc transporter mRNA expression in peripheral blood mononuclear cells by real-time quantitative PCR
Inflammation (CRP, IL-1, IL6, TNF-alpha) by rate nephelometry or similar

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: - Adults, age 18-65 y - Have not been diagnosed with major illness
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: - Diagnosis of major illness - Taking of prescription drugs which known to interact with zinc - Women who are pregnant or breastfeeding

trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation using a randomisation table created by computer software (i.e. computerised sequence generation)
trial_design.statisticalmethods: The sample size for this study is 40. There is no literature on zinc transporter expression under these intervention conditions. We feel a sample size of 40 is reasonable for a pilot study.

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Level 1, 40 Mount Street, North Sydney NSW 2060

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Sub-groups of the Australian population are considered at risk of zinc deficiency but uncertainty remains in the interpretation of zinc biomarkers. Zinc has no definable, accessible body stores. Our proposal aims to explore the usefulness of zinc transporters, which regulate the movement of zinc into and within-cells, as potential biomarkers of zinc status in humans. We aim to examine the feasibility of using peripheral blood mononuclear cells for the assessment of zinc status. If our approach is successful we will have the potential of investigating zinc status in greater detail.

ethicscommitee.ethicaddress: Level 2, Margaret Telfer The University of Sydney NSW 2006 Australia
